name: 3.Model Classification
content:
The H2O Distributed Random Forest (DRF) algorithm is employed for training the prediction model.

DRF is a robust machine learning algorithm optimized for large-scale datasets, making it well-suited for predicting HCP engagement using Social Determinants of Health (SDOH) factors.


Steps for Model Training

1. Initialize H2O Environment

  • Start an H2O cluster.
  • Import the SDOH dataset into the H2O environment.

2. Data Preparation

  • Train-Test Split: Divide the dataset into training and testing subsets.
  • Target Variable: hcp_engagement (numerical score of healthcare provider engagement).
  • Feature Set: Include relevant SDOH factors such as:
  • emp_cnt
  • usage_score
  • days_to_pay
  • and other socioeconomic indicators.

3. Model Training (DRF)

  • Train a Distributed Random Forest model in H2O.
  • Specify key hyperparameters:
  • ntrees → number of trees
  • max_depth → maximum depth of trees
  • min_rows → minimum number of rows per leaf


Model Summary & Outputs

After training, H2O generates a detailed model summary, including:

  • Performance Metrics: Accuracy, AUC, Precision, Recall, F1-score.
  • Feature Importance Rankings: Identify the most influential SDOH factors.
  • Visualization Tools: Tree-based variable importance plots and ROC curve outputs.
